clinical_study.brief_title: Different Modes of Ventilation During Cardiopulmonary Bypass
clinical_study.official_title: Comparative Study Between Different Modes of Ventilation During Cardiopulmonary Bypass and Its Effect on Postoperative Pulmonary Dysfunction

brief_summary.textblock: 66 patients divided into 3 groups with different modes of ventilation.

detailed_description.textblock: Sixty-six patients going through open-heart surgeries were included in the study, divided into 3 groups (P: pressure controlled ventilation, V: volume controlled ventilation, C: control) in accordance with the mode of ventilation. Patients studied for chest x-ray, lung ultrasound, arterial oxygen partial pressure to fractional inspired oxygen ratio (PaO2/FiO2), Alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient, static lung compliance and dynamic lung compliance, taken after induction of anesthesia, 1h post cardiopulmonary bypass, 1h after arrival to cardiac surgical unit.

primary_outcome.time_frame: after induction of anesthesia, 1hour post cardiopulmonary bypass and 1hour after arrival to cardiac surgical unit.
primary_outcome.description: Chest x ray to detect any lung pathology or changes from baseline like pleural effusion, pulmonary edema or pneumonia

primary_outcome.time_frame: after induction of anesthesia, 1hour post cardiopulmonary bypass and 1hour after arrival to cardiac surgical unit.
primary_outcome.description: Lung ultrasonography to detect any lung changes from baseline or development of consolidation, pulmonary edema or pleural effusion

arm_group.description: During cardiopulmonary bypass period the patients were ventilated with volume-controlled ventilation
During cardiopulmonary bypass period the patients were ventilated with pressure-controlled ventilation
During cardiopulmonary bypass period the patients were disconnected from ventilator

intervention.description: Changing modes of ventilation during cardiopulmonary bypass
Applying pressure controlled ventilation during cardiopulmonary bypass Period

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients undergoingvalve surgeries
- Patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting surgeries
Exclusion Criteria:
- Emergency cases.
- Off-pump surgeries.
- Patients with chronic lung diseases with forced expiratory volume in first second (FEV1) or forced vital capacity (FVC) less than 40% of the predicted value.
- Massive blood transfusion during surgery.
- Complicated surgeries.
- Redo surgeries.
- Patients with decompensated heart failure prior to surgery.
- Patients refusal
